story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Fyne Ales has struck gold in a prestigious industry awards scheme.One of the Cairndow-based brewery#s best-selling products, Hurricane Jack, won gold at this year’s national SIBAIndependent Beer Awards.The fruity blonde ale advanced to the national finals after topping the Scottish cask heats in , seeing off stf competition to be named the UK’s best cask bitter up to . per cent.Hurricane Jack is brewed using US Amarillo and Cascade hops. First brewed in  along with its partner brew Vital Spark, Fyne Ales describes Hurricane Jack#s flavour as #a biscuity malt with balanced sweet citrus and smooth floral flavours and a lightly bitter finish#.Fyne Ales has a long history of success at the awards across cask, keg and bottle and can, with this year#s national gold rounding out an impressive haul of trophies in the   season.Neil Walker, chair of judges at the awards, said: #Massive congratulations to all of this year’s finalists. Not only did we see a huge sixty percent increase in entries compared to last year but the quality of entries was genuinely astounding, with some truly inspiring businesses in the running.#A special fundraising coffee morning is to be held in Inveraray for the United Nations refugee agencyand Red Cross campaigns to help Ukrainian refugees.As well as delicious coffee, tea and cakes, look out for a raffle, tombola and#haircuts.You#ll have to go along to discover where the haircuts fit in to a morning filled with fun for a great cause.It all happens at Inveraray church hall on Saturday April  between .am and .pm.Peter Baxter, curator of Benmore Botanic Garden near Loch Eck has been awarded Royal Horticultural Society Associate of Honour  for outstanding services to horticulture.The title is given for le, with just  people holding the award at any one time.With over  years# experience as curator at Benmore # run by the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh , Peter has undertaken signicant fieldwork in Bhutan, Chile, Japan, Australia and North America and successfully introduced considerable numbers of conservation plants to Benmore and widely within RBGE#s Living Collection.A major achievement has been the successful restoration of the Victorian fernery at Benmore, initially constructed in s. The transformation of this exceptional construction has created a major new focus in the garden.It is a unique building in a remarkable setting, occupying a remote site at Benmore, on a steep south-west facing hillside, with a clf on the eastern side forming an integral part of the structure. The ferns on display are from many parts of the world, all from temperate or warm temperate regions.He has overseen the successful fundraising and restoration of the Grade A-listed Golden Gates, initially made in Berlin in  for the then owner of Benmore, the sugar refiner and philanthropist James Duncan. Today, they sit resplendent as the entrance from Glen Massan to Benmore House.Benmore Botanic Garden specialises in plants from cool and wet temperature regions, particularly from the Himalaya, Bhutan, Japan, Chile and western USA.Rhododendrons, coners and ferns are well represented throughout the garden.It is home to the -year-old Redwood avenue, one of the finest entrances to any botanic garden. The Benmore team works hard maintaining and developing Benmore and their support is greatly appreciated by Peter.

title: shinty round up saturday march 26 2022 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowAll the goals came in the second half as Inveraray beat Oban Celtic - at Ganavan in shinty#s Mowi National Division.Depleted due to Covid and injuries, Inveraray held Celtic in a goalless first-half.A more promising start to the second half from Inveraray saw the deadlock broken as Craig Taylor put Inveraray ahead on  minutes. The goal settled the Royal Burgh side, and Lewis Montgomery added a brace on  and  minutes.In Mowi South Division , Kilmory ran out - winners against a young Oban Celtic second team at sun-drenched MacRae Park, Lochgilphead.Goals from Sandy Leiper on  minutes and three by Alex Cunninghamsealed the points for the Kilmory.The home side enjoyed a good first half and would be disappointed with aof just two goals. Play was more scrappy in the second period but Kilmory managed to close out the match.The club thanks Crinan Construction for sponsoring the match and all the supporters who came out to watch.In the same ision, Inveraray and Bute juniors drew - at the Winterton.Bute started the match strongly, using their pace and youth to advantage. It did not take long for Craig Speirs to gave the islanders the lead on six minutes, rling home from the angle.Two minutes later Inveraray were level, Neil Campbell showing scoring from  yards.Bute again took the lead in the th minute when Aray failed to clear and Aiden McGregor took advantage.The home side settled into the game after that setback and started to play some decent shinty, though, despite creating numerous chances, the sides went into half time with the score - to Bute.Inveraray started the second half the better of the two sides, giving the youthful Bute side problems settling.With Inveraray pressing it took until the th minute for the equaliser to arrive Neil Campbell again driving the ball home. Bute pressed to find a winner but the Inveraray backline held firm.In the Women#s Camanachd Association Mowi South Division , Dunadd Camanachd scored three goals in either half to defeat Uddingston - at St Ambrose High School in an excellent advert for women#s shinty # both teams fielding young players with a bright future ahead.Dunadd looked slightly nervy starting their first game of the season but a well-taken goal from Eilidh Cameron settled the team.The next  minutes were end-to-end but the Dunadd defence stayed strong with some excellent saves from stand-in goalie Laurene Cameron.At the other end  Eilidh E Cameronwas tenacious and set up Dunadd#s second as she slotted the ball to Rhian McCuaig, who finished superbly for her first goal for the club.Uddingston, though were not going to give up and, after a spell of pressure, Christie Robertson struck an excellent shot straight in the top corner.Dunadd didn#t let heads go down. After some excellent play on the wing, Alice Adair found striker Eilidh Cameron whose shot was judged to be kicked away by the goalie.Cameron didn#t hesitate from the spot and finished low to the goalie#s left.In the second half Dunadd#s experience started to show as they settled into the game.McCuaig completed her brace, Nicola Smyth finished from close in and Cameron went on to get her hat-trick.That winning feeling # Kilmory#s Sandy Leiper in their match against Oban Celtic juniors. Photo: Andrew Sinclair. no_aShintyKil_ObCelt_Sinclair

title: sustainable living ideas create a buzz in tayvallich
story: Updated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMore than  people attended Tayvallich#s first sustainable living pop-up event on Saturday April .Visitors and villagers sampled local produce, exchanged ideas, swapped seeds, bought and swapped second-hand garments and repaired clothes at the event in the village hall.Locally made household goods and toiletries were on sale alongside artisan bread made in the village and pork products from the neighbouring Keills peninsula. The owners and the chef from the Tayvallich Inn handed out free samples of their home cooking featuring local ingredients including Murray#s salmon and Little Keills pork.A Tayvallich resident attending the event said: #There was such a great vibe, people chatting about everything from renewable energy, laundry, repairs and growing veg # so many ideas and such a lot of enthusiasm.#PICno_aTayvallichPopUp. Tayvallich Village Hall was set up to host a wide iety of eco-living stalls

title: your pictures may 28 2021 2 2 2 3 2 2 2 2 2 2 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowTaken just across Loch Fyne from Tarbert, this week#s featured photo was submitted by a reader from Cowal # too modest to be named, sadly # from the site of the controversial #ark# on the hills above Tighnabruaich.The sculpture of Noah#s Ark was built # without planning consent, though later permitted # to provoke thought about the climate crisis by local environmentalist and woodworker David Blair.The sculpture has been featured many times in this and other publications, but the site on which it sits is stunning, and the photographer was standing close to the ark for the photograph.To the left is the Isle of Bute, with Tighnabruaich and Kames on the opposite side of the Kyles of Bute. The island of Inchmarnock can be seen in the distance to the left, with Kintyre visible in the right hand distance.

title: selkirk-teenager-wins-gold-boxing-scotland-youth-elite-championships
story: SELKIRK boxer Charlie Dent won a gold medal in the  .MKG category at the Boxing Scotland Youth and Elite Championships at Ravenscraig, Motherwell on Sunday March .The ft -year-old Earlston High School pupil beat Lochend’s Christian Pacitti to claim the title.The Edinburgh fighter took a standing eight count in the first round and was unable to continue for the second leaving Dent to claim gold.Dent will now undertake an assessment week with the Boxing Scotland squad with a view to representing his country.Charlie Dent picks up gold He told the Border : “I was over the moon with the victory. It was a great experience. I come from a boxing family and love the sport. It keeps me fit and out of trouble. My first fight was in January  and since then I’ve fought -times and I’m now looking forward to the trials. I’d love to box for Scotland but my ultimate goal in the future would be to turn professional.”Dent trains at the Borders Boxing Gym in Selkirk run by his grandfather Pat Mulroy who is a professional boxing coach and both parents, Billy and Vikki who are also coaches.Proud mum Vikki said: “We are incredibly proud of Charlie. We opened the Borders Boxing Club in  but because of the pandemic this is really our first proper season. We are passionate about helping boxers in the Borders progress to the top levels and improving health and wellbeing in the local community.“We run classes for –-year-olds, -adults non-competitive and our boxers group to provide a pathway for aspiring young boxers. Hopefully having a champion in the club will help increase the profile.More information about the club can be found on their facebook page https:www.facebook Bordersboxingclub

title: melrose-7s-draw-full
story: The draw for this year’s long-awaited Melrose s has taken place.In the opening fixture Glasgow Hawick face Musselburgh with the winners taking on French side Seventies.Stirling will take on Hawick with the winners facing the British Army in the second round.Boroughmuir face Currie with the winners taking on Fijian side Lomaiviti.Selkirk face Ayr with the winners taking on the winners of the Kelso v Co-optimists game.Samurai meet Heriot’s and will face whoever triumphs in the Gala v GHA match.Edinburgh Accies take on Jed-Forest and the winners will face the London Scottish Lions.Peebles fave Aberdeen with the winners taking on Melrose.Marr play Watsonians with the winners taking on Belgium.Tickets are still available for what is sure to be a fantastic day.

title: co-optimists-delighted-back-greenyards
story: THE invitational Scottish rugby union club, affectionately known as The Co-Optimists will be ing to the Melrose Rugby Sevens tournament on Saturday th April  to compete for the  Centenary Cup.The Co- Optimists, have had many greats of the game play for the side, including local legend Doddie Weir, and notable other internationals such as Finlay Calder, Jonathan Davies, John Jeffrey, as well as Gavin and Scott Hastings.The team last won the Melrose Sevens in , when Doddie was a key player for the team.Co-Optimists President Euan Kennedy said “We are delighted to accept an invitation from Melrose Rugby to attend this year’s Sevens event. It is our intention to bring an exciting and very competitive side to the Greenyards, with a number of high-profile names in keeping with our tradition. The team will be co-coached by Steve Lewis and local Melrose stalwart Scott Wight.“It is also a particular delight to attend this year, as we know that the club are supporting My Name’ Doddie Foundation, Doddie is a former Co-Optimist, indeed he was part of our last winning team back in , so it is a fabulous opportunity for us to support him and his charity.”Featuring for the Co-optimists will be Kenyan rugby s star Collins Injera who currently holds the second place for number of tries scored on the World Rugby Sevens Series with .He represented Kenya in Rugby Sevens at the  Tokyo Olympics – becoming one of only a handful of players across the globe to have played in both the  and  Olympics.Injera is also the first Kenyan rugby player to represent the country in three consecutive World Cups and three consecutive Commonwealth Games.Also playing will be South African rugby legend Cecil Afrika who’s one of the most celebrated Springbok sevens player of his generation.England ’s legend Tom Varndell who is one of the quickest wingers in the game, has had caps for England ’s and England sevens and is known for his prolic try scoring rate will also make his Greenyards debut..removeHe currently plays on the wing as a player-coach for Bury St Edmunds and has represented other Premiership Rugby sides including the Bristol Bears and Wasps. He is currently the leading try scorer in Premiership.Doddie Co-Optimists Melrose Sevens Tournament Director Phil Morris said, “We are excited to see the Co-Optimiststo the Greenyards, we know they will be bringing a very competitive team and entertaining squad for everyone to enjoy.”Scott Wight added, “As a local lad with a proud association with Melrose Sevens I’m thrilled to be talking with a lot of great players from all over the world with a view to getting them to become Co-Optimists and the guys are excited at the prospect of being part of our side at the Melrose Sevens. We look forward to revealing the players in due course”Melrose RFC are also offering kids the opportunity to meet Collins and Cecil as part of a very special coaching session. This unique training session will be held at The Greenyards on Thursday  April.Commencing at : both Kids and parents are invited to watch an hour training session featuring Co-optimists stars before participating in a fun kids coaching session from :-: led by Southern Knights Coach Bruce Ruthven featuring Cecil and Collins.This event is FREE and open to all P,P and S kids in the Scottish Borders, it will take place on the G pitch.Book here: https:melroses news melrose-sevens-coaching-session

title: borders-youngsters-heading-france-six-nations-festival
story: THERE IS a strong contingent from the Scottish Borders in Scotland U Men’s Head Coach Ross Miller’s squad for the Six Nations Festival in Marcoussis, France from Saturday April  to Wednesday April  .A -player extended squad came together for the first time in early March following club and school fixtures which identied players for the FOSROC Scottish Rugby Regional Championship series, with players from outwith Scotland identied through the Scottish Qualiedprogramme.The numbers were then reduced to  including Marcus Brogan from Hawick, Monroe Job from Selkirk, Ben Weir from Melrose, Luke Townsend from Earlston High School and Melrose, Hector Patterson from Jed-Thistle and Kerr Johnston from Gala.Scotland will open their Under- Six Nations Festival campaign by playing their Italian counterparts on Saturday  April , on Wednesday  April they will play Franceand their final game of their festival campaign will be against England on Sunday  April . All three games will be available to watch via a live stream.Scotland U Head Coach Ross Miller said: “Im delighted to be taking  talented rugby players to France this week for their first taste of international rugby.“To narrow the squad down to  players has been tough. The  players who were in our extended playing group put their hands up for selection and although we couldn’t select everyone all the players have worked hard and are showing a continued appetite for self-development which is an important part of the programme.“The standard of players we’ve been able to select from was very high. They have all come into the programme with a good all-round skill set and rugby knowledge which is testament to the development they’ve had in their club and school environments as well as the FOSROC Scottish Rugby Regional Championship series.”Scotland Under- Six Nations Festival Squad.removeForwards Jerry Blyth-Lafferty , Marcus Brogan , Tom Currie , Robbie Deans , Monroe JobAlfie Maitland , Liam McConnell , Elliot Young , Euan McVie , Ruaraidh Hart , Ben Weir , Bartlomiej Brylak , Callum Smythand Sam Wallace Back: Luke Townsend , Amena Caqusau , Hector Patterson* , Andrew McLean , Alexander Thom , John Ventisei , Euan Muirhead , Kerr Johnston , Murdock Lock ,Finlay Thomson , Jack Brownand Logan Jarvie Scotland U Men’s FixturesSaturday  April: Scotland U Men v Italy Marcoussis, France Wednesday  April: Scotland U Men v France Marcoussis, France Sunday  April: Scotland U Men v England Marcoussis, France

title: borders-recorded-150-covid-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  cases of coronavirus in the last  hours, new figures show.The Scottish Government published updated statistics at pm today .And the new figures show the Borders has now recorded , cases of COVID- since March .There are  people in hospital in the region with recently confirmed cases – eight fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now seen ,, cases since the pandemic began.There are , people in hospital across the country.

title: hawick-based-company-emtelle-expand-north-america
story: A BORDERS-BASED cable company is set to expand into North America in what has been described as a “landmark moment”.The move by Emtelle will create up to  jobs, according to a spokesperson for the firm.The Hawick-headquartered company, which employs  staff worldwide, is aiming to open up a facility in Fletcher, North Carolina.The announcement follows the firm’s recent acquisition of Dubai-based AfriPipes.:Police told not to pursue -year-old Borders motorist twice over accident fearsTony Rodgers, Emtelle CEO, said: “Our US expansion marks a landmark moment for Emtelle.“With an estimated multi billion dollars to be invested in fibre rollouts across the US in the next five years, the new manufacturing facility in Fletcher will better position us to ensure our customers across the US have access to our high-quality product range.”The firm describes itself as “a leading global manufacturer of pre-connectorised, blown fibre cable, and ducted network solution”.

title: border-union-show-return-two-years-cancellations
story: IT will be business as usual at a traditional Borders agricultural show this summer after two years of cancellations.The Border Union Agricultural Society at Springwood Park in Kelso is hard at work planning two major events – Crufts qualier and Championship Dog  Showand the Border Union Agricultural Show .The Border Union Show, a true celebration of rural le, will give visitors a close encounter with all the best in food and farming produce in the region.It will be the first opportunity since  local livestock farmers have had to showcase their best in breeds in the ring and the appetite is well and truly back.:Borders-based cable company set for ‘major’ US expansion in ‘landmark’ momentThe Border Union Show is well-known for its equestrian flavour with judges travelling theand breadth of the country to give their seal of approval to an array of classes and disciplines competing in the rings.A full compliment of trade and food stands will be in place during the classic ‘Bake and Create’ industrial section, with a food hall and craft and gt marquee.Peter Douglas, the Border Union Agricultural Society chairman, said: “The directors and trustees are united in ing with a traditional show that will embrace the farming and rural community that represents all that is special about the Borders and north Northumberland.“Emerging from the shadows of the pandemic we are all geared up for business as usual. A full programme will be out later in the year but for now, save the dates, and come and enjoy the show.”Pre-show tickets at a  per cent discount are now available at: borderunion border-union-show visitors tickets

title: schloss-roxburghe-partners-kelso-rfc-member-benefits
story: A BORDERS hotel, spa and golf course has created a partnership with a local rugby team to help build a "positive relationship" with the local community.The SCHLOSS Roxburghe Hotel in Heiton near Kelso, has partnered with Kelso RFC to share special offers with club members.New and existing club members will be able to access a range of benefits through the hotel, which both organisations hope will encourage more people to join the club and visit Poynder Park – the home of Kelso RFC.Bruno De Schuyter, general manager at SCHLOSS Roxburghe, said: "The club is an integral part of the local community and we strongly believe that it is important that we build alliances and partnerships in our region and support each other wherever we can."Building up a positive relationship within the local community is incredibly important to SCHLOSS Roxburghe."The strength of community lies in the strength of the connections that we have with each other."As a large company which will impact the socio-economic climate within our local area, community engagement is paramount."Benefits on offer to Kelso RFC members include discounts on food and drink at the hotel and golf course, vouchers for a round of golf for two as well as a three course dinner. There are also offers on fishing tuition, green fees and on retail items.Mr De Schuyter added: "The club will benefit from a range of discounts including food and beverage, green fee, fishing and retail stock from the professional shop."The club will also be provided with vouchers enabling them to attract new memberships. SCHLOSS Roxburghe will also be donating prizes for their raffles."The current benefits are for this [rugby] season, however it is our intention have a long and positive relationship within the local community."

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-31-april-4-1997-1972-1922
story: A LOLLIPOP man told of his devastation at being accused of being over-friendly towards youngsters, reported the East Lothian Courier of April , .Parents are rallying round to support their kiddies’ lollipop man, off work suffering from stress after being carpeted by his superior for being over-friendly towards children.Bob Pollock , who has shepherded children over the busy cross-roads at the end of Knox Place, Haddington, for eight years, was devastated by the rebuke and for days sat, upset, in his home, spent sleepless nights and couldn’t eat.“I felt as though I was accused of being some kind of pervert,” he said. “I was told there had been a complaint and it had to be investigated.”Bob, , admits patting children on the head and on a couple of occasions putting a finger down a child’s neck while joking, “It’s cold today – feel how cold my hands are”. But he strenuously denies any sinister motive, saying there were always parents around. ...and  years ago‘Bingo – the first seeds of destruction’ was the warning in the East Lothian Courier of March , .The move to start bingo sessions in North Berwick’s only cinema because of the failing business was described this week by a resident as being “just the first seeds of destruction for North Berwick”.The resident — who wishes to remain anonymous — told the Courier: “I have come from a place where bingo started two nights a week and then it crept in every night and now it is open Saturdays and Sundays. Now the Bingo shops are open from  in the morning and you can imagine the type they bring into the place – busloads of people and the experience of the residents has been disgusting. When the place empties they just use the first door they come to as a public toilet.“I have seen it all happen before, it is just the first seeds of destruction for North Berwick. It will finish the place. It will finish the High Street.” ...and  years agoChildren at Saltoun school enjoyed “amusing conjuring tricks”, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .Through the generosity of Mrs Fletcher of Saltoun, the pupils attending the public school here were entertained to a treat on Friday evening. The first part of the entertainment consisted of a number of clever and amusing conjuring tricks, performed by a gentleman from Edinburgh.The children watched the tricks being performed with great interest, and many of them departed for home fully under the impression that they knew how the tricks were done. The children then sat down to an excellent tea and did ample justice to all the good things provided.

title: tims-tales-reaching-core
story: The results of a recent study on the effects of storytelling on children in hospital, published in the scientic journal PNAS , state: “We found that, compared with an active control condition, one storytelling session with hospitalised children leads to an increase in oxytocin, a reduction in cortisol and pain, and positive emotional shts.” It concluded that “these important clinical implications affirm storytelling as a low-cost and humanised intervention that can improve the wellbeing of hospitalised children”.Oxytocin is the feel-good emotion, often associated with childbirth, but which can play a role in reducing stress and anxiety for us all. It’s a hormone which helps build trust and attachment, as opposed to cortisol, which increases stress levels.We do sometimes need cortisol when faced with a challenge or fearful situation, so it does have its . It’s part of our fight and flight response. But the problem arises when levels remain too high for an extended period of time, as this keeps our bodies under a constant state of stress.When this happens, it can cause anxiety and depression, but also lots of physical issues such as headaches and tummy pain. It’s very dficult to concentrate and remember things when we are in this state.The study showed that for children in hospital, a time full of stress and worry for many reasons, storytelling resulted in an increase in oxytocin levels and reduction of cortisol, and so made the children feel less anxious and stressed, and even helped ease their physical pain.While the context of this research was children in the very stressful situation of being in hospital, I think the results and conclusions are also relevant for children in other stressful settings, including at school and home. I’m not making a direct comparison, but we’ve not had ‘normal times’ recently, and even in usual times, high levels of stress can be a big issue for many. So levels of stress and anxiety are heightened, even beyond the ‘normal’ for many of us.Some of the language in the article is related to the science of the findings, but the conclusions and observations are things teachers, parents and storytellers of all kinds will recognise. It describes how children being told the story “are transported to another possible world during storytelling sessions” and can “elicit positive physiological and psychological changes”. In other words, it can have a positive effect on physical and mental health.This transportation to “another possible world” is what storytellers often refer to as the story trance. It’s when children are absorbed in a story, and taken by their imagination to the world the story creates. The report explains that this absorption stimulates ious parts of the brain and aids the listener’s development of empathy, as well as a better understanding of their own emotions.None of this is really surprising, of course. But it’s really useful to have this kind of scientic back-up. An important finding was that the stories told were ones widely available and not specically adapted for therapeutic use just the kind of tales you find in a book from the library.And while they used professional storytellers for the research, a key point was that everyone can have this impact, including parents and caregivers: “It is important to note that even though we have used experienced storytellers for our research purposes, we believe that parents should be encouraged to tell their children stories. As we have shown, it is not necessary to use special stories or books or even specic techniques to achieve a successful outcome. Storytelling can be an effective means of creating important emotional bonds.”As I have said, this study looked at the impact of storytelling for children in hospital, which can be a deeply distressing time for both child and parents.Reading the report made me remember the time I was seven years old in the Western General Hospital, in an isolation ward by myself, very ill. I was told a story about a dragon who lived in a castle, and was given a model castle, made from used toilet rolls, and painted silver. I’d look at it when I was alone, which I always was except for visits. It was a stage for my imagination. I’d speak to the dragon and imagine the adventures I’d have with him when I finally got out of hospital. These stories were always my secret, but they helped me get out of hospital and have fun, when in the real world I could do neither.The thing is, our kids, as well ourselves, need this. The story is part of it, the characters, the challenges, the suspense, the connection to the emotions in the tale. It all works on our brain and our being. But it’s also the process of storytelling: the togetherness it creates, the shared space and attention, the heart-to-heart connection, the stimulation of imagination. Not even the best film on a screen does that.We are all storytellers, but sometimes it is good to be reminded just how important it is to be so, and that includes listening to, as well as telling, stories.As the report concluded: “Stories possess a symbolic dimension that seems to create a natural bridge to the core of our humanity.”

title: leading-pig-farmers-plea-cabinet-secretary
story: Mairi Gougeon MSP was accompanied by county MSP Paul McLennan on the visit to one of several high-health pig farms run by Mr Wyllie.Pig farms across Scotland are all operating at a substantial and growing loss.Mr Wyllie, of Ruchlaw Mains, Stenton, estimates that losses of about £ per pig in February last year have since deepened to more than £ per pig. Overdrafts are rising at an alarming rate and several Scottish farmers have already sold off sows to cut losses.The pig sector encountered signicant disruption during the Covid- pandemic which affected processing capacity and saw the partial closure of Scotland’s largest pig abattoir facility at Brechin.Much to the disappointment of NFU Scotland, several major retailers have continued to stock signicant volumes of imported pork, undermining, the union says, home production.And the dramatic spike in animal feed prices in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine has also signicantly increased the scale of current losses on pig farms.It is in the interests of Scottish consumers, processors, and retailers, adds the union, that farmgate prices for pigs rise immediately to stave off a rapid rate of herd liquidations.Speaking on behalf of NFU Scotland, Mr Wyllie thanked the Cabinet Secretary for the pig hardship scheme in Scotland, established following the Covid-driven closure of the Brechin abattoir, but called on her to consider further immediate, direct support for the sector to ensure a critical mass of production was preserved.He also asked for the Scottish Government to consider an ‘Ongoers’ loan scheme to help financially support those who saw their future in the industry.NFU Scotland called on the Scottish Government to seek greater retailer support for Scottish pork, highlighting that a small percentage increase in the volume of home-produced pork on supermarket shelves would make a considerable dference.Help in re-establishing the Chinese export licence at Brechin, lost because of the Covid outbreak at the plant, would also expand the market opportunities for Scottish pig producers.At a UK level, NFU Scotland called for the Scottish Government to push Westminster on the need for “proper border controls” to monitor pork imports and for the English language requirements for overseas butchers looking to come to the UK to work in the staff-strapped processing sector to be relaxed.

title: six-county-schools-come-together-climate-change-event
story: Teams of  pupils had to produce a plan for a product or initiative and an accompanying poster and presentation, which was made to a judging .Belhaven Hill School hosted the event, which was attended by pupils from Gordonstoun Junior School, Strathallan Prep School, Ardvreck, Fettes Prep and Cargilfield, earlier this month.The categories for the climate change event were defined by the annual Earthshot Prize, with each team choosing from: the restoration and protection of nature air cleanliness ocean revival waste-free living and climate action.Olly Langton, Belhaven Hill headmaster, said: “We want to ensure our pupils know that they can have a signicant impact on their environment now and in the future.“So my we Rosie and I came up with the idea of developing a Community of Prep and Primary Schoolsin Scotland to energise the children and bring them together to form an alliance to protect the things they love.“We were also keen to involve members of the local Dunbar community, where there is a strong environmental ethos which encourages collaboration.”The teams presented to a  of judges from the sustainability sector: Jonathan Hodges, senior innovation engineer at Wave Energy Scotland Duncan Lang, senior environment specialist at the Asian Development Bank and Izzy Heard, technical officer for the Climate Disclosure Project.The lists introduced themselves before watching each -minute presentation and giving immediate feedback.The teams completed a number of environmentally themed talks and activities, while Surfers Against Sewage encouraged youngsters to ‘Think Global Act Local’.“It was a pleasure to hear the great ideas and passionate presentations from this next generation of climate-aware thinkers,” said Mr Hodges.“The projects started by these students have already created positive change in their schools and communities, and I have no doubt they will follow-up with more.”In the afternoon, pupils took part in the Scottish Prep Schools Debating Championship – the motion challenged the children to consider whether short-haul flights should be banned.Edinburgh’s Cargilfield triumphed in both competitive elements of the day.The prize for outstanding inidual award on the day went to a pupil from Ardvreck, who went away with a voucher for a surfing lesson at Belhaven Bay, thanks to the generosity of CoastCoast.The next day, the bay was also the location for the first ForthSHORE beach clean by pupils from Belhaven with GreenTweed Eco.All the children took away a bird box, thanks to the East Lothian Primary Schools Bird Box Project, sponsored by ArdMoor, and a certicate.The next stage of the venture is for all of the schools to take part in a joint fundraising venture in the summer term. It will raise money for the initiative and charity chosen by Cargilfield, which was their prize for delivering the best presentation.

title: former-bank-turned-new-home
story: Royal Bank of Scotlandclosed its branch on North Berwick’s Westgate in .Since then, plans have come forward to convert the site of the single-storey bank hall, which is attached to a Category-B listed building, into a three-storey property, complete with wine cellar and rumpus room in the basement.Those proposals were turned down after meeting a wall of objection from the community, while councillors were keen to see office space remain in the town centre.Despite repeated attempts to secure planning permission and listed building consent, no plans were approved.Now, fresh proposals are with East Lothian Council for the former bank building to be brought back into use.The latest plans, from Patricia Sharp, would see the building remain single-storey.Inside, two bedrooms would be created, alongside a home office store, lounge and dining and kitchen area.A supporting statement included with the latest application notes the prior intention was to demolish the former banking hall and for a new home to be built on the site.Now, the developer is asking East Lothian Council to approve a change of use from a bank to a single flat.The document reads: “It is now well established by the means set out in adopted policy that the former bank has no commercial attraction in the North Berwick market.“It is understood that any replacement building, whether in a modern or traditional mould, would attract opposition from neighbours, from those living in Westgate, and those concerned with the amenity of North Berwick.“In addition, the committee and the LRB [Local Review Body] have made their views clear.“Accordingly, a change of use would preserve the building’s footprint, massing and style, and would send an important signal about the beneficial attractive use of buildings which have fallen out of use or have been abandoned by their commercial occupants.”Christiane Maher, treasurer of North Berwick Community Council, confirmed that the latest plans would be discussed at the group’s next meeting on Tuesday.

title: north-berwick-trust-looking-expand-board
story: The trust – a charity which holds millions of pounds from a land sale to use to benefit local groups – currently has eight members on its board but is looking to add four more to compliment and expand its skillset.The positions are for an initial three-year term and are suited for those with a strong connection to North Berwick and time to dedicate to the role.The trust is particularly interested in finding new trustees with the following skills: legal expertise audit expertise construction project management construction risk management architectural expertise land management and grounds maintenance expertise surveying historic building conservation empathetic to the view of young people, perhaps with children in one of the North Berwick schools reliable and patient ability to prioritise issues and possess good time management confident communicator critical thinker tactful, honest and trustworthy.Young people are encouraged to apply for the positions, as well as iniduals not already committed to other voluntary organisations.To apply, submit a tailored CV and cover letter to cath@northberwick trust before pm on April .Shortlisted candidates will be invited to meet the group, with appointments to be made in June.

title: musselburgh-groups-provide-free-taster-sessions-help-boost-covid-recovery
story: Project , launched by Musselburgh Area Partnership, which distributes a council budget to local schemes, welcomed applications for funding, with a total of £, on offer to community organisations.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: “The pandemic has had a huge effect on all aspects of our lives. This project helps clubs and organisations to reconnect with people of all ages and, through these additional taster sessions and activities, goes some way to help reduce social isolation and improve the mental health of people throughout our community.”The groups which applied and received between £ and £ were:l Wallyford Parents  Carers Councilfor a gardening taster session open to the whole communityl East Lothian Schools – Active Schools to provide pupils at Musselburgh Grammar School with taster sessions, including CrossFit, gymnastics and dance, which will all be delivered in partnership with local sports coaches and clubsl Sporting Memories Foundation Scotland to deliver reminiscence, social and inclusive physical activities that improve the mental and physical wellbeing of isolated people aged  and over living with dementia, depression and other long-term conditionsl First Step Community Project to offer a iety of taster sessions focusing on wellbeing, including cooking, arts, pilates yoga and walkingl Whitecraig Village Hub for taster activities such as fitness, yoga pilates, sporting activity and creative crafts. It is hoped that this will encourage the local community to re-engage with the new facility and try out new activitiesl Eskmuthe Coastal Rowing Club to provide young people an opportunity to learn to rowl Musselburgh Art Club for three taster sessions to encourage new members interested in or considering arts and crafts, painting in acrylic, oils, watercolour, gouache or pastels, or crafts including felting, making cards for special occasions, calligraphy and embroideryl Musselburgh Sea Cadets to provide taster sessions created as part of the National Sea Cadets Growth and Development Team to give young peoplean insight into the activities of the sea cadetsl Musselburgh Old Course Golf Club for a joint project with Cycling Without Age, opening the doors to the clubhouse on the first Tuesday of every month, when members of the community can enjoy social activities and entertainment after arriving, and then departing on a trishaw – a three-wheel cycle with a passenger cabl Clark Community Choir to provide free come and try sessions to both adults and young people accompanied with an adultl Changes Community Health Project to offer activities around supporting people’s wellbeing, connecting with nature, connecting with other people and tackling social isolationl Musselburgh Congregational Church’ TGI youth group to introduce young people over  to curling, supported by the curling club at Murrayfield in Edinburgh.

title: letter-week-vital-lifeline-communities
story: Fast forward to East Lothian in . Poverty is very much still with us, even within our most well-off communities. East Lothian Council has an updated poverty strategy and the local area partnerships have had specic funding to tackle poverty and inequalities.The pandemic, Brexit and the war in Ukrainehave all added to the pressures on prices of le’s basics, from food to transport and utilities. A rural area like ours has many who rely on heating oil, which is now about £ a litre. Many in the villages have no public transport and need to run a car.I attend the East Lothian Friendly Food Network – a council-supported network of those involved in food from across the county. Many of those who attend are from the county’s foodbanks and community pantries.The Scottish Government recently ran a consultation on how the need for foodbanks may be ended. However, all facilities in East Lothian report growing calls for support.Those needing help include, as well as those on benefits, increasing numbers of those on low pay who find that the cost of basics is a growing proportion of their weekly income.There have been mounting calls for food that does not need cooking. There are increasing requests for help to pay for gas and electricity. The charges to those on prepaid meters are higher and the top-ups on a card last for much less time than before.One organisation has been giving hot water bottles as it’s cheaper to boil a kettle to fill a bottle than turn the heating on. Organisations across the county are arranging free community meals. Breakfast club provision for children is expanding to ensure children do not go to school hungry.I recently attended a national conference where the cost of living crisis was debated. The experience identied in East Lothian is replicated across the UK.The Chancellor’s Spring Statement could have given much more help than it did. Benefits and state pension remain lagging behind the rate of inflation and could have been increased VAT could have been reduced on fuel for heating, lighting and cooking the uplt in Universal Credit could have been restored the increase in National Insurance waived. Sadly, those with the least income are those who lost out and will continue to see the cost of living eating into their weekly money pot.In the meantime, residents can continue to support the many excellent local organisations offering support, whether as donations of food, money or volunteering time. They remain a vital leline for some of the most vulnerable in all our communities.Jacquie Bell Belhaven

title: reveals-north-berwick-one-uks-best-seaside-towns
story: The town received an overall rating of %.The list was compiled by reviews from more than , visitors who gave feedback on their recent trips to seaside towns, villages and resorts.Destinations were rated on their beaches, attractions, value for money, peace and quiet, and scenery.North Berwick scored the following for these categories:Beach:  Attractions:  Value for money:  Peace and quiet:  Scenery:  On Tripadvisor, visitors to North Berwick praise the town for its day trips, excursions and sights to see. Of nearby Tantallon Castle, one reviewer speaks of the "exceptional views and location".Top of the list for the UK was Bamburgh in Northumberland. It won visitors over with its stunning scenery, beach and peaceful surroundings.North Berwick placed sixth overall.The Which  summary of the top rated destination said: “The former  winner is back on top thanks to its five-star beach.“This glorious stretch of golden sand runs for three miles, backed by a vast, tussock dune system and dominated by the epic Bamburgh castle.“The beach is big enough that it’s rarely crowded, which may suit those looking to socially distance this summer.“The bracing wind off the North Sea also helps to keep mass tourism at bay and the beach pristine and free of litter.“This is the British seaside at its low-key best: nothing to do here except walk, run, let the dog off the lead, or sit behind a windbreak with a Thermos and watch the waves roll in.”You can see the full list here.

title: aldi-lidl-middle-aisles-sunday-april-3
story: Whether it’s Aldi’s Specialbuys or Lidl’s Middle of Lidl, the latest offers are always worth checking out and there are some fantastic buys from April .Lets take a look at some of the items you can buy this week...Aldis Specialbuys section is full of handy DIY items, garden furniture and camping gear from April .Gardenline Rope Coffee  Piece Set, pictured. Photo via Aldi. From rattan chairs to classy, grey sets, garden furniture is a big feature in this weeks Aldi Specialbuys.If the early Spring sunshine inspired you to rejuvinate your outdoor spaces, the Gardenline Rope Coffee  Piece Set is perfect for a garden makeover. The stunning rope effect furniture, just £., set in grey is ideal for patios or conservatories and hosts and hostesses with the mostest. For those looking for Mediterannean-inspired garden furniture in muted colours, the Gardenline Wicker Effect Bistro Set includes a table, two chairs with both seats and back cushions and a stunning glass top table.Priced at £., this is the perfect set for calming Summer evenings with a book, glass of wine and nibbles. Pictured, Aldis Gardenline Wicker Effect Bistro Set. Photo via Aldi.Aldis Specialbuys from April  also features the Ambiano Electric Grill, ideal for cooking for the whole family for both camping and family BBQs at home.For just £., you can cook up some delicious treats on this grill, which features a non stick aluminium coated die cast plate, removable drip tray and stabilising frame.For those looking to go on a camping adventure this year, Aldi has a range of handy supplies for less.This includes the Adventuridge Air Windbreak , Adventuridge L Water Carrierand Adventuridge L Waste Water Carrier .One of Aldis top-selling Specialbuy items this week is the LED Lamp  Mosquito Zapper, priced at £..Offering four to  hours of torch light, the LED zapper is the perfect solution for unwanted insects on your camping trip.Ideal for caravans or small rooms, Aldi is offering a Specialbuy deal on this ." Caravan TV with a DVD player .With breathtakingly sharp : images, this TV has a built in HD triple TV turner, HDMI port, a USB port, a built in media player and more. It is perfect for those who want to place a TV in their kitchen or childs bedroom. Read more like this: You can find the full list of Aldis Specialbuys from April  on the website.Lidl has stepped up the Middle Aisle offer this week with great home and garden products as well as DIY tools.The Lino Home Table Lamp With Touch Dimmer from Lidl. Photo via Lidl. Lets take a look at some of the best Middle of Lidl products on offer from Sunday, April .If you need to invest in some quality dishware and pans for less, Lidl has a great selection. One of the most interesting finds in Lidls Middle Aisle this week is the atmospheric Lino Home Table Lamp With Touch Dimmer .Featuring a frosted glass shade for calming, warm light and a metal base with a matt-nickel finish, the lamp has a touchand touch-sensitive lamp base for switching it on and off.You can also switch between three dferent brightness levels.The black Ernesto cm Forged Aluminium Casserole Dishis durable, non-stick, oven safe and suitable for all hob types.It also promotes healthier frying, Lidl said, as the high-quality cooking surface means less oil is required.Other top kitchenware from Lidl includes the Tefal L Pressure Cooker , Ernesto Stoneware Oven Dish Dish Setin ious bright colours and Ernesto Forged Aluminium Frying Pan Wok .Some Middle of Lidl products on offer from Sunday, April . Photos via Lidl. Just in time for a good Spring clean, Lidl is selling this all-purpose Parkside Wet  Dry Vacuum Cleaner for £.. You could use it to clean workshops, the garage, DIY or the car while it also doubles up as a blower and extracts water.Even better, the hoover comes with three years warranty.For those who prefer a cordless vacuum, Lidl is featuring the Silvercrest -in- Cordless Vacuum Cleanerin this weeks Middle of Lidl.This vaccum offers an extra long run time of up to  minutes, three speed settings, bagless technology with a double filter system, rotating motor-powered suction brush and more.For steam and dry ironing, Lidl is selling the Silvercrest Steam Generator Iron with three years warranty for just £..Ready in just  seconds, this iron can be used for efficient steam and dry ironing.You can find the full list of new Middle Aisle products via the Lidl website.

title: make-easter-eggs-home-chocolate-moulds-lakeland
story: As a tradition, lots of chocolate is consumed on these days and we’re not complaining.Each year there seems to be even more chocolate on offer in the shops and you can grab it well in advance of the celebrations.Or you can take it to the next level this year and have a go at making your own Easter eggs." alt"East Lothian Courier: Chocolate eggs made with Lakelands Easter Egg Moulds " class"editor-image"Chocolate eggs made with Lakelands Easter Egg MouldsLakeland is giving its customers the chance to get creative this Easter with its Easter Egg Moulds.Not only can you make a large hollow chocolate egg with the set, but you can also make solid mini eggs.: Morrisons launches Easter range with chocolate eggs and hot cross buns - See the range: Krispy Kreme set to launch Easter doughnut range in April - See the doughnuts hereThe set includes two moulds which will help you make a large chocolate egg and there’s four moulds so you can make  mini eggs.Whether you want to make treasure hunts that more fun or experiment with dferent designs, these Easter Egg Moulds could be the ideal tool." alt"East Lothian Courier: A decorated Easter egg, made using Lakelands Easter Egg Moulds " class"editor-image"A decorated Easter egg, made using Lakelands Easter Egg MouldsFor just £., you could have hours of fun making delicious chocolate eggs, perfect for treating yourself or gting to those around you.If you’d like some inspiration, you can follow this Chocolate Egg Nests recipe or learn how to temper chocolate via the Lakeland blog website.: Myprotein and Hotel Chocolat reveal chocolate Easter egg for  - how to get yours: Cadbury reveals Easter chocolate range for  with  new items - See the full listThe set of Easter Egg Moulds is available to buy via the Lakeland website.

title: youth-allegedly-found-green-herbal-matter-north-berwick-high-school
story: The incident was reported to local police on Friday and the -year-old boy was reported to the authorities.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: "A -year-old male youth has been reported in connection with this incident."This incident was reported to police on Friday, April ."An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: “North Berwick High School has clear expectations for pupils’ behaviours which all of our young people and families are aware of."In cases where these standards are not met we will deal with them in line with our agreed policies."We work in partnership with local police officers to ensure the safety of our community, including when incidents of antisocial behaviour occur outwith school hours.”

title: couple-setting-new-dance-centre-east-linton
story: ArtEastDance will be based at The Mart in East Linton and run by professional dancing couple Sarah Jane Medley-Marchand and Jerome Marchand.Sarah Jane, who is originally from the village, recently ed home after years spent in Stockholm with the Royal Swedish Ballet and Les Ballets des Monte Carlo.She now s with a wealth of expertise and experience hoping to foster the next generation of dancing talent in the county.Sarah Jane said: “I grew up in East Lothian and wanted to come back after more than  years away.“We have a five-year-old daughter and I wanted her to be close to family too. I’m very lucky that Jerome was happy to follow me as he loves Scotland.“We went for a walk to look around East Linton when we first arrived from Sweden and we found The Mart.“Formerly used for auctions, The Mart is now a thriving community hub housing ious local businesses, including a yoga studio, guitar maker and farm shop.“We thought it was a great space and amazing opportunity to open our new dance school.”The school will offer ballet classes for all ages as well as modern dance, barre classes, progressive ballet technique and private coaching in a new, fully equipped studio.“At ArtEastDance, we will have a small, fully equipped studio to start, which we will hopefully expand in the future, with wall-to-wall mirrors, a sprung floor and ballet barres from Harlequin,” Sarah Jane said.“We can’t wait to bring our -years-plus experience as professional dancers to teach what we love to children and adults in a fun and friendly environment.”

title: north-berwick-beauty-salon-named-regions-best
story: Studio Soleil, on Forth Street, was nominated for best beauty salon in the country at the awards at the DoubleTree by Hilton in Glasgow, and took home the prize of the best in the south of Scotland.The salon has been open for nearly five years, offering everything from sunbeds to massages and facials.Christelle Woodcock, head therapist at Studio Soleil, said it was an honour to claim the award and seeing an East Lothian salon gaining recognition at the national level made it that bit more special.She said: “It was such a great honour to see that Studio Soleil is getting recognised for the hard work that me and the girls do here.“For us to bring North Berwick’s name to the map was definitely something special.”Christelle herself was also nominated for the best beautician in Scotland, making it to the final six, and was overjoyed with reaching that stage.

title: dunbar-walking-football-group-celebrates-cash-boost
story: Dunbar Walking Football Group offers people with a love of the game the chance to step onto the pitch, without the need for a turn of pace.The group, which was formed in the summer of , regularly attracts more than  people to the twice-weekly sessions at the town’s Hallhill Sports Centre.Now, the group has received £, through the National Lottery Awards for All Scotland.Colin Mackay, a trustee for Walking Football Scotland, has been involved with the Dunbar group for about four years.He was delighted to receive the funding and said: “We are vulnerable adults and our average age is in our early s.“We look to encourage guys to come back out and play.“During Covid, you had to play outdoors, which suited us.“The main thrust was to get the funding to get those involved decent waterproof rain jackets and protective clothing.”The group is largely made up of people over the age of , although the footballers include people living with Parkinson’s and Down’s syndrome. People living with or recovering from major illness or injury are also welcome to join the group.Mr Mackay, , said: “We play non-contact and below head height to avoid head injuries.”

title: judy-murray-tennis-coach-makes-surprise-appearance-longniddry
story: Longniddry Tennis Club opened its new pavilion on Saturday, attracting hundreds of locals to the tennis courts on Douglas Road.Attendees were delighted by a surprise visit from Judy Murray and Mel Benson.Judy Murray is the former captain of the GB Fed Cup team, now known as the Billie Jean King Cup, and has been a tennis coach for more than  years.She is mother to Wimbledon champions Jamie and Andy Murray and holds  Scottish titles herself.On Saturday, Judy tweeted: "Crashed the Open Day at Longniddry Tennis and delivered an impromptu parent-child session with Mel Benson and club coach, Euan Cameron."Eight years ago these two public courts were derelict."Amazing community effort to raise funds to resurface them and create a clubhouse.’"FUN. FRIENDS. FAMILIES.Crashed the Open Day at @LongniddryTenni + delivered an impromptu parent-child session with @MelBenson + club coach Ewan.  years ago these  public courts were derelict. Amazing community effort to raise funds to resurface them + create a clubhouse.👌 https:t.co ycqKYdNcj pic ZVTzPfsvThe official opening of the club house took place at midday with David Vince, a stalwart club member, cutting the ribbon.David project managed the whole building process for the new clubhouse and the upgrade of the courts.David Vince cut the ribbon for the brand new club house at around pmFollowing the refurbishment, Longniddry Tennis Club now offers two all weather floodlit courts and a new clubhouse.The club, which is open to players of all ages and abilities, will offer memberships and a pay and play option.Well done @LongniddryTenni club for a fantastic -hour community day for the opening of the new clubhouse. Great turnout  atmosphere 👏 Brilliant from @JudyMurray supporting the event  delivering a surprise parent  child session 💥🎾👌 #showcase #empowering #inspiring pic SyAXhrQBFA comprehensive coaching programme for juniors and adults, club sessions and an opportunity to play competitive tennis are all also available.Children and adults enjoyed a tennis taster session with Judy and MelLucy Bryden, on behalf of the tennis club, said: "Judy was amazing and had all the kids and adults on court playing and having a lot of fun."The upgrade in facilities would not have been possible without the support from so many people and organisations."The club with help from members and local community fundraised a signicant portion of the funding to complete the transformation."Grant funding for the pavilion was received from sportscotland, East Lothian Council, Coop Good causes, Tesco Community grant, Wemyss and March Estate, The Matthew Good Foundation, Longniddry Rotary and Foundation Scotland and an interest free loan from the Lawn Tennis Association."Forever Spaces fitted the kitchen in the clubhouse free of charge.Stewart Harris, sportscotland’s chief executive, said: "These have been challenging times for everyone, so it is so encouraging to see clubs and communities like Longniddry remaining committed to providing opportunities for participation in sport and physical activity."I’m delighted that we were able to provide £, of National Lottery funding to improve the clubhouse at Longniddry Tennis Club to ensure that even more people will have access to tennis."This will not only allow the club to be more inclusive and accessible but will also provide a vital social space right at the heart of the community."Around £ was raised at the Tennisathon on the day, while residents can continue to donate to the JustGiving page at https:www.justgiving campaign Longniddrytennisclub.The money raised will be used to help complete the finishing touches to the pavilion and to support ongoing tennis activities for all ages within the community.

title: wordle-290-april-5-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you’re still trying to save your streak, then don’t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today’s word starts with the letter N and ends with the letter L.It has one vowel but it is repeated twice. What is today’s Wordle answer, Tuesday, April  If you have given up on today’s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.   The Wordle for April  is NATAL. The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: “Since launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.“The game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .“It has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me – from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.“On the flip side, I’d be lyingI said this hasn’t been overwhelming.

title: full-time-working-couple-struggle-rent-one-bed-glasgow-flat-cost-living-soars
story: Andrew Fry and his partner, who doesnt want to be named, have been left worrying where they will live as their energy bills are set to skyrocket.The two young professionals, both aged , currently live in a £ a month two bed flat in Partick, but it has no insulation or double glazed windows leaving them hit hard with heating bills.Andrew Fry is looking for a flat in Glasgow It comes after a UK Government decision to increase the energy fuel cap by a whopping %, leaving millions of people scrambling to find a way to survive.The pair must now consider downsizing to a one bed flat in a similar area to save money, but were shocked to find prices the same or higher for smaller properties.Andrew said: “It just feels like an impossible task, we both work full time and it is still hard to rent a one bedroom flat.“Our flat just isn’t energy sufficient. We have said to the landlord that our energy prices are going up, which is a huge increase in our costs of living, but they don’t have plans to add double glazing or insulation.“They know they can fill the flat fast and maybe even put up the pricethey like, so why would they bother to improve it for us.“We have been looking for something  but the prices landlords are asking for are so unreasonable, they know can get away with it because there is such a high demand.“People are charging more than £ for a small flat that hasn’t seen so much as a lick of paint since  and it is accepted because that is just the standard.”Andrew is hoping they can find a more energy efficent flat that will allow them to cover their soaring energy bills.It comes as their estimated monthly spend in winter was around £, but now Shell energy have recommended they pay £.The pair are also hoping to buy thei brown property in the future but admitted it feels like a ‘fantasy’ idea and they try to keep afloat in the cost of living crisis.  Andrew said: “It isn’t hard to see how people fall into homelessness or hard times, I work hard but it would only take me not being paid for about two months for me to fall into serious trouble.“It is easy for people to slip under, it can happen to anyone and with bills going up to much more people are at risk.“We would love to buy our own property but even though we both work full time, it seems like a fantasy idea.“How could we ever do that with rent increasing and housing bills going up, it would be impossible.“I don’t have high hopes of things getting any better anytime soon, with the war in Ukraine, Covid, and energy bills going up we need a break and some serious help.”We are looking for readers to share their experiences of the rising cost of living whether that be energy bills, rent, food prices or fuel.
